name: skew
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
to cause something to be not straight or exact; to twist or distort: These last-minute changes have skewed the company's results.

Add to word list
Add to word list
to cause information or results to be changed: Biased questions can skew the results.
Add to word list
Add to word list
to cause results, figures, profits, etc. to seem higher or lower than they really are: Independent researchers have concluded that the study was poorly designed and that its inclusion in the report could skew results. The average property price is skewed by strong activity at the upper end of the market.skew sth toward(s) sth The FTSE 100 index is skewed towards large oil shares, banks and other multinationals.
